text: He maketh the storm a calm, so that the waves thereof are still.
text_kjv: He maketh the storm a calm, so that the waves thereof are still.
text_niv: He stilled the storm to a whisper;the waves of the sea were hushed.
text_esv: He made the storm be still, and the waves of the sea were hushed.
text_nlt: He calmed the storm to a whisperand stilled the waves.
text_msg: He quieted the wind down to a whisper,put a muzzle on all the big waves.
text_nasb: He caused the storm to be still, So that the waves of the sea were hushed.
context: Psalm 107 is a hymn of thanksgiving, a call to those redeemed by the Lord to express their gratitude. It is likely a post-exilic psalm, composed after the return of the Israelites from Babylonian captivity (around 539 BC). The psalm employs a recurring pattern: a description of distress, a cry to God for help, God's deliverance, and a call to thanksgiving. This pattern echoes the historical experience of the Israelites, who frequently faced adversity and oppression before being delivered by God. The psalm recounts four specific scenarios of distress: wandering in the desert (verses 4-9), imprisonment (verses 10-16), sickness (verses 17-22), and storms at sea (verses 23-32). Each of these situations represents different types of hardship that the Israelites, both collectively and individually, would have faced. The imagery of the sea was particularly significant, as the ancient Near East often viewed the sea as a chaotic and threatening force, a symbol of the untamed and unpredictable aspects of life. The psalmist uses vivid language to depict the power of the storm, emphasizing the helplessness of those caught in its fury. The profession of various occupations underscores the universality of God's grace, available to every stratum of society. The final verses of the psalm (33-43) reflect on God's sovereignty over both blessing and calamity, urging wise people to consider these things and understand God's steadfast love.
meaning: Psalm 107:29, "He maketh the storm a calm, so that the waves thereof are still," speaks powerfully to God's sovereignty and omnipotence. The verse highlights God's ability to control the very forces of nature, transforming chaos into peace. The storm, in this context, can be understood both literally and metaphorically. Literally, it refers to the violent storms at sea described earlier in the psalm, demonstrating God's power over the physical world. Metaphorically, the storm represents any form of overwhelming difficulty, trouble, or suffering that humans may encounter. This verse asserts that God is not merely present amidst the storm; He has the power to quell it completely. The words “He maketh” emphasize God's active role and deliberate action. It is not a passive observation of the storm subsiding but a divine intervention that brings about the calm. The phrase “so that the waves thereof are still” underscores the completeness of God's action. It is not just a temporary respite but a lasting peace, a cessation of the turmoil. The stillness of the waves symbolizes the tranquility and security that God provides in the face of adversity. The verse reflects a deep theological truth about God's character: He is a refuge and a source of hope in times of trouble. It affirms His unwavering presence and His capacity to bring peace to the most chaotic situations. This verse offers comfort and assurance to those who are struggling, reminding them that God is able to calm the storms in their lives.
application: Psalm 107:29 offers profound implications for modern living. We all face storms – personal crises, financial difficulties, relationship problems, health challenges, and even global events that feel overwhelming. This verse reminds us that we are not alone in these storms. God is present and powerful. Practically, it means we must first acknowledge our need for God's intervention. We can't always solve our problems on our own. Recognizing our limitations allows us to turn to Him in prayer and supplication. Seeking God's guidance and strength is a crucial first step. Secondly, the verse encourages us to trust in God's timing and plan. The calm may not come immediately, but we can be assured that God is working behind the scenes. Cultivating patience and faith during difficult times is essential. We can find solace in knowing that God's ultimate purpose is for our good, even if we don't understand it in the moment. Third, the verse invites us to be agents of calm in the lives of others. When we have experienced God's peace in our own storms, we can offer comfort and support to those who are currently struggling. Sharing our testimonies of God's faithfulness can be a powerful way to encourage and uplift others. Fourth, we can apply this verse to societal issues. In a world often characterized by conflict and injustice, we can pray for God to bring calm and peace. We can actively work towards reconciliation and justice, knowing that God's ultimate desire is for shalom – a state of wholeness and harmony in all of creation. Finally, remember that the calm described in this verse is not merely the absence of trouble but a deep, abiding peace that surpasses understanding. It is a peace that comes from knowing that God is in control, even when circumstances seem chaotic. Cultivate this inner peace through prayer, meditation, and a consistent focus on God's Word.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you today, acknowledging that you are the Lord of all creation, the one who stills the storms. I confess that there are times when I feel overwhelmed by the challenges of life, as if I am tossed about in a raging sea. Please, Lord, bring your calm into my life. Still the waves of anxiety, fear, and uncertainty that threaten to engulf me. Grant me the peace that surpasses all understanding, a peace that anchors my soul in the midst of the storm. Help me to trust in your timing and your plan, even when I cannot see the way forward. Use me as an instrument of your peace in the world, that I may offer comfort and hope to those who are struggling. Thank you for your unwavering presence and your unfailing love. In Jesus’ name, I pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: No, this verse doesn't guarantee instant cessation of all difficulties. It assures of God's power to calm, offering peace *within* the storm, even if the external situation persists. It's about trust in His presence and sovereignty during hardship.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Does this verse mean that God will always immediately stop all storms in our lives?

faqs.answer: The event in the Gospels (Matthew 8:23-27, Mark 4:35-41, Luke 8:22-25) where Jesus calms the storm is a direct manifestation of the power described in Psalm 107:29, revealing Jesus' divinity and fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy.
faqs.question: Q2: How does Psalm 107:29 relate to Jesus stilling the storm in the Gospels?

faqs.answer: "Make" implies divine intervention. It's not a passive observation of nature taking its course, but God actively exerting His power to change the circumstances, showing His sovereign control.
faqs.question: Q3: What does it mean to 'make' a storm calm, as opposed to simply letting it calm down?

faqs.answer: Yes. While personal application is vital, the verse's principle of God's power over chaos applies to societal issues. We can pray for peace, justice, and healing, believing God can influence even large-scale events.
